DOC.HEAD: Western Creditors May Advance Yugoslavia Up to $4 Billion
DOC.TEXT: Western creditors may lend Yugoslavia up to $4 billion in the next two years if it adopts Premier Ante Markovic's new market-oriented economic program, sources and press reports said Thursday. Yugoslav banking sources told The Associated Press the International Monetary Fund agreed to grant Yugoslavia an 18-month stand-by credit worth $600 million. The loan, once fully approved by IMF authorities, will be available from Jan. 1, 1990. Yugoslavia hopes the IMF will increase that to $900 million for a two-year period, said sources close to the negotiations, which ended in Belgrade this week. The newspaper Vecernje Novosti said Yugoslavia now has a shot at obtaining additional Western credits, because commercial banks and governments usually follow the IMF lead in gauging whether to keep supporting a debtor country. It quoted National Bank Vice Gov. Zarko Trbojevic as saying the World Bank, the European Community, the IMF and the European Free Trade Association have already agreed to grant Yugoslavia a total of $3 billion in new credits. Italy, Japan and Canada have also ``given guarantees'' to supply Yugoslavia with additional loans worth about $1 billion in the next two years if Markovic's reform package is put into effect, Vecernje Novosti said. The money would be used mainly for importing new Western technology and restructuring Yugoslavia's economy and its banking system, which is being reformed in accordance with Western standards, the sources said, speaking on condition of anonymity. They said money was needed to prop up banks that have been backing money-losing ventures that would lose government subsidies under market-oriented reforms. Markovic has apparently won a battle in Parliament against conservatives who oppose his efforts to introduce market mechanisms into the economy _ now burdened by a 2,000 percent inflation rate, a $17 billion foreign debt and a 17 percent unemployment rate. His reform package calls for compulsory shutdown of all money-losing firms, wide introduction of private and foreign investments, wage freezes and tight monetary and budgetary controls. Yugoslavia on Wednesday became the first communist country to introduce convertible currency when part of Markovic's program was adopted in parliament. Communist leaders in Serbia, Yugoslavia's largest republic, oppose Markovic's efforts to restructure the state-run economy and promote greater political pluralism, but his measures are likely to be adopted despite the opposition. About 650,000 workers held a half-hour warning strike in Belgrade, the capital, on Wednesday to protest planned austerity measures, Tanjug news agency reported.
